section.title: Install Options
section.para: JBoss Developer Studio can be installed in a number of different ways.
You can install JBoss Developer Studio, packaged with Eclipse and dependent third party plug-ins, with a universal installer for all operating systems.
Alternatively, if you already have Eclipse on your system you may prefer to install JBoss Developer Studio BYOE. This option installs JBoss Developer Studio onto Eclipse.

section.title: Install JBoss Developer Studio
section.para: A universal installer .jar file is provided for installing JBoss Developer Studio and it is available from the Customer Service Portal.

Alternatively, the source code is also available as a .zip file at the same location. You can use this source code to build the universal installer yourself and then use that to install JBoss Developer Studio. Maven must be installed to build the universal installer from the source code.
Both options are detailed in the procedure below.

step.para: Log in to the Customer Service Portal at https://access.redhat.com.
From the menu bar click Downloads then, under JBOSS ENTERPRISE MIDDLEWARE, click Downloads.
From the Product list, select JBoss Developer Studio.
From the Version list, select 7.0.0.
Complete the appropriate step for your chosen install option:
For installing from the provided universal installer, from the table click Download for the JBoss Developer Studio 7.0.0 Stand Alone Universal Binary download file.
For installing from a source-built universal installer, follow these steps:
From the table, click Download for the JBoss Developer Studio 7.0.0 Source Code download file.

On the command line, navigate to the location of the .zip file and enter unzip jbdevstudio-product-sources-7.0.0.build_version.zip where build_version is substituted to match the name of the downloaded file.

To build the universal installer, on the command line navigate to devstudio/product and enter mvn clean install Building takes some time to complete, after which the universal installer .jar file is located in installer/target/.

On the command line, navigate to the location of the universal installer .jar file and enter java -jar jbdevstudio-product_universal-7.0.0.build_version.jar where build_version is substituted to match the name of the .jar file.
To start the installer, you may be able to double-click the .jar file.
When the Installer window opens, click Next.
After reading and agreeing to the terms of the End User License Agreement, click I accept the terms of this license agreement and click Next.

In the Select the installation path field, type the location where you want JBoss Developer Studio to be installed or click Browse to navigate to the desired location. When the Select the installation path field shows the correct location, click Next. When you are prompted about the selected location being created or overwritten, check the message and, if satisfied, click OK.

Default Java VM is automatically selected. Ensure that the disabled text field contains the path of the JRE in the Java developer kit you want to use. If it does not, click Specific Java JVM and type the path of the JRE in the text field or use the Browse button to select the correct JRE. When the text field shows the correct JRE path, click Next.

important.para:
You must specify a 32-bit JRE to install a 32-bit version of JBoss Developer Studio and a 64-bit JRE to install a 64-bit version of JBoss Developer Studio. To change the bit version of the JRE to be used for installing JBoss Developer Studio, complete the appropriate step for your operating system:
On OS X operating systems, from the Installation type list click the appropriate bit version.
On Linux distributions and Microsoft Windows operating systems, type the path to the appropriate bit version of the JRE.

step.para: To make use of automatic runtime detection for finding application servers, click Add. Type the path from which recursive scanning for application servers should commence or click Browse to navigate to the path. To detect a specific application server, select the install directory for that application server. To detect multiple application servers, select a directory higher up the directory tree. If you want this path to be scanned for new application servers each time JBoss Developer Studio starts, select the Scan every start check box. Click OK to close the Add Location window and click Next.
Check the details in the Summary Information window and, if they are correct, click Next.
Installation commences. When the Pack installation progress bar shows Finished, click Next.
If you want shortcuts to be created for starting JBoss Developer Studio, select the Create shortcuts in the Start-Menu and Create additional shortcut on the desktop check boxes and click Next.

The installation process is now complete. If you want JBoss Developer Studio to automatically start when the Installer window closes, select the Run JBoss Developer Studio after installation check box. Click Done to close the Installer window.

important.para: Linux distributions have a maximum number of files that a process may have open at one time. If this maximum number of files is set too low, JBoss Developer Studio will not start. You must open the /etc/security/limits.conf file and check that the soft nofile and hard nofile variables have values of 9216 at a minimum. If the variables have smaller values, the values must be increased to 9216. If the variables are not specified, the following lines must be added to the file: * soft nofile 9216 * hard nofile 9216

section.title: Install JBoss Developer Studio BYOE
section.para: You can obtain JBoss Developer Studio BYOE from Eclipse Marketplace or use the .zip file available from the Red Hat JBoss Developer Studio Update website.
Select one of the procedures below, which will guide you through the JBoss Developer Studio BYOE installation process.

step.para: Start Eclipse Kepler.
Click Help→Eclipse Marketplace.
In the Find field of the Search tab, type JBoss Developer Studio and press Enter.
Locate JBoss Developer Studio (Kepler) and click Install.
Ensure the JBoss Developer Studio (Kepler) check box is selected and click Next.
After reading and agreeing to the licenses, click I accept the terms of the license agreements and click Finish.

During the installation process you may receive warnings about installing unsigned content. If this is the case, check the details of the content and if satisfied click OK to continue with the installation.

Once installing is complete, you are prompted to restart Eclipse. Click Yes to restart now and No if you need to save any unsaved changes to open projects. Note that changes do not take effect until Eclipse is restarted.
Start Eclipse Kepler.
Click Help→Install New Software.
In the Work with field, enter https://devstudio.jboss.com/updates/7.0-development/.
From the table of components comprising the update .zip file, select JBoss Developer Studio 7.0 - Bring Your Own Eclipse and click Next.
Verify the details of the component to be installed and click Next.
After reading and agreeing to the licenses, click I accept the terms of the license agreements and click Finish.

During the installation process you may receive warnings about installing unsigned content. If this is the case, check the details of the content and if satisfied click OK to continue with the installation.

Once installing is complete, you are prompted to restart Eclipse. Click Yes to restart now and No if you need to save any unsaved changes to open projects. Note that changes do not take effect until Eclipse is restarted.
